pageContext.claim: “We have ended the disastrous defense sequester. No money for the military, those days are over.”
pageContext.analysis: Obviously, the military received plenty of money -- about $600 billion a year -- even after the 2011 enactment of the budget deal that introduced the sequester, intended to bring some budget discipline to Washington. Congress increased spending caps by $32 billion in 2013 and $40 billion in 2015, in a partial easing, and then completely eliminated the caps in the most recent budget agreement. As a technical matter, the sequester was not officially eliminated.
